awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding the Fundamental Principles Driving Household Energy and Resource Consumption for Smart, Sustainable, and Resilient Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Ultimately, the amount of energy and resources that Americans consume depends heavily on where as well as how they live. Thus residents of northern states tend to consume more energy at home than residents of southern states, because heating requires more energy than cooling. Similarly, people living in suburbs tend to consume more energy for transportation than people living in city centers because longer commutes consume more energy. Similar observations can be made for all types of energy and resources, from electricity and transportation to natural gas, water, and even food. This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant will help to discover the fundamental principles that govern how much "where" and "how" people live matters for energy and resource consumption. The contributions from this research will directly assist in the development of effective policies for more sustainable communities that consume less energy and resources. Moreover, a better understanding of energy flows in cities will provide planners and engineers with information that will enable them to design smarter and more resilient infrastructure systems that are decentralized and distributed. In addition, this grant will have a significant impact for the broader public as it includes the development of a smartphone application to enable anyone to calculate their daily carbon footprint and track their performance over time.

This research places itself at the nexus of urban metabolism and complexity theory. Urban metabolism is the study of flows of material and energy in cities. The main hypothesis of this research is that urban metabolism follows distinct mathematical laws at the community scale that can be captured using elements of complexity theory. Various mathematical laws (e.g., power law, lognormal distribution, uniform distribution) will be applied using agent-based modeling techniques to generate a theoretical space that will include every possible community profile in terms of energy and resource consumption. These laws will then be tested for individual communities using freely available data from municipal open data portals. Additionally, this research will utilize elements of machine learning to classify communities based on their energy and resource consumption patterns, and network science to better understand the inter- and co-dependence between the usage of electricity, water, natural gas, and transportation infrastructure. The research will therefore offer a significant contribution to help design a society that is smarter and more resilient while being more sustainable by requiring less energy and fewer resources to thrive.

por.por_cntn:
What you are doing right now, reading these words, would not be possible without the often seamless and constant operation of civil infrastructure systems. In fact, the daily activities of most people across the U.S. and in many parts of the world would not be possible without constant and reliable access to water, wastewater, transport, electricity, solid waste management, and telecommunication infrastructure. Yet, no one fully understands how infrastructure functions as whole. From small, local systems in the nineteenth century, many infrastructure systems have grown to be highly interconnected and massive, sometimes spreading over multiple cities, states, or even over multiple countries. Nowadays, when one infrastructure system is affected, others get affected too--think of the impact of a power outage, a water main break, or a bridge collapse--directly affecting the resilience of infrastructure and the people who are serviced by it. This point applies to the demand for infrastructure as well since it is also highly interrelated--think of how electricity, water, and gas consumption increased in residential areas during the pandemic as people stayed home. Moreover, operating and maintaining this infrastructure requires an excessive amount of energy and resources that is unsustainable. In the twenty-first century, infrastructure planning and design practices must evolve.

By focusing both on the supply of and demand for infrastructure, the major goals of the project were to understand and detect the presence of fundamental principles and mathematical patterns in how households consume energy and resources within cities. Energy and resources included electricity, natural gas, water, and even transport. The project included the analysis of the interrelationships in how energy and resources are consumed (e.g., how electricity consumption is interrelated with water and gas consumption and travel demand). The research goals were tackled both theoretically and empirically. Empirically, we used energy and resource consumption data from open data portals and other data platforms from public and private institutions, and we used machine learning and complexity science tools to capture meaningful information from the data (e.g., tree-based learning, deep learning, network science). Theoretically, we developed an understanding of the principles that govern and limit urban infrastructure systems in how they work individually and collectively (e.g., identifying interdependencies).

This project resulted in more than 40 scientific contributions, several openly accessible codes, and the textbook Urban Engineering for Sustainability (MIT Press, 2019). The results from this project can offer practical guidelines to help plan and design smart, more sustainable, and more resilient infrastructure.
